body: Confirmed, this looks like a bug. I’m guessing the multi line string concatenation is messing with the rule logic.

I looked into it and found that it's related to the placement of the variable in concatenation instead of multi-line concatenation:


-  code: `var foo = "Hello" + test + "world"`  => fixed code: `var foo = ` \``Hello ${test} world`\`
-  code: `var foo = "Hello " +  "world" + test`  => fixed code: `var foo = ` \``${"Hello " + "world"}${test}`\`
-  Similarly for multi-line concatenation.

### [Check fixed code in online demo](https://eslint.org/demo#)

The fixed code is not incorrect in any case, just the format used in the cases is not consistent.

I am looking more into it, if I can come up with a fix for this.

issue.title: fix: improve fixer of `prefer-template` rule

issue.body:

-->

    - Include tests for this change
    - Update documentation for this change (if appropriate)
-->

<!--
    The following is required for all pull requests:
-->

#### What changes did you make? (Give an overview)

Resolve https://github.com/eslint/eslint/issues/15083

**Before**

code: `var foo = "Hello " + "world " + test` => fixed code: var foo = `${"Hello " + "world "}${test}`

**After**

code: `var foo = "Hello " + "world " + test `=> fixed code: var foo = ``Hello world ${  test}``

#### Is there anything you'd like reviewers to focus on?
No

body:
> 1. Unwanted space `${  policyViolationReport`

That's intentional because this rule doesn't know user's preferences about spacing in `${}`. This spacing can be automatically fixed in subsequent iterations by [template-curly-spacing](https://eslint.org/docs/rules/template-curly-spacing) and/or [no-multi-spaces](https://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-multi-spaces) rules.

> 2. Unwanted line break for the closing clause ` };` of the last literal variable:
> 
> ```js
> + "report-to "}${  policyViolationReport
>  };`);
> ```

That's intentional, it is assumed that the line breaks were there for readability.
 
> 3. For some reason, `"default-src 'self' https://*.google.com;"` is represented as a placeholders (`${expression}`), while in fact it's just a text, not a variable in contrast to the `policyViolationReport`, which really should be represented as a literal placeholder — `${policyViolationReport}`.

This looks like a bug.

> 4. BTW, the line break with literals can be implemented without concatenation symbols `+`, e.g.:
> 
> ```js
> `string text line 1
>  string text line 2`
> ```

It wouldn't be the same string value, because line breaks in template literals contribute to the value.

For this code:

> ```js
> res.setHeader("content-security-policy",
> 		"default-src 'self' https://*.google.com;"
> 		+ "script-src 'self' 'unsafe-eval' 'unsafe-inline' https://*.google.com;"
> 		+ "connect-src 'self' https://*.google.com;"
> 		+ "frame-ancestors 'none';"
> 		+ "report-to " + policyViolationReport
> 		+ ";");
> ```

I think the output should be:

> ```js
> res.setHeader("content-security-policy",
> 		"default-src 'self' https://*.google.com;"
> 		+ "script-src 'self' 'unsafe-eval' 'unsafe-inline' https://*.google.com;"
> 		+ "connect-src 'self' https://*.google.com;"
> 		+ "frame-ancestors 'none';"
> 		+ `report-to ${  policyViolationReport
> 		  };`);
> ```

> This spacing can be automatically fixed in subsequent iterations by [template-curly-spacing](https://eslint.org/docs/rules/template-curly-spacing) and/or [no-multi-spaces](https://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-multi-spaces) rules.

In my case, both rules are enabled:

```json
"no-multi-spaces": "error",
"template-curly-spacing": "error"
```

But I still get the declared result. The `--fix` option is enabled in the IDEA settings.

> > This spacing can be automatically fixed in subsequent iterations by [template-curly-spacing](https://eslint.org/docs/rules/template-curly-spacing) and/or [no-multi-spaces](https://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-multi-spaces) rules.
> 
> In my case, both rules are enabled:
> 
> ```json
> "no-multi-spaces": "error",
> "template-curly-spacing": "error"
> ```
> 
> But I still get the declared result. The `--fix` option is enabled in the IDEA settings.

It works with ESLint's multipass autofix (`--fix`), please check the Fixed Code tab in [this demo](https://eslint.org/demo#).

> When I click on **ESLint: Fix: `prefere-template`** in IDE

Maybe in this case your IDE doesn't run fixing through ESLint, but applies only that single fix. Each auto-fixable problem has an [EditInfo](https://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/nodejs-api#-editinfo-type) property, which is the info on how to fix the code for that problem. Integrations can use this property to manually apply fixes if ESLint's built-in multipass autofix isn't what's needed for a particular use case.

I believe, I figured out the nature of the issue.

In case of fixing the issue via CLI, a proper result is received right after execution this *sole* command, while fixing an issue via IDEA UI requires more steps to be done manually: IDE returns an option with an extra space, which needed to be fixed separately.

Originally, the file was quite big and that's why there was a significant delay between fix and rescan. I assumed, that the result was a final-one, but in fact I should wait more time, until IDEA prepares the updated inspection outcomes.

> > 1. For some reason, `"default-src 'self' https://*.google.com;"` is represented as a placeholders (`${expression}`), while in fact it's just a text, not a variable in contrast to the `policyViolationReport`, which really should be represented as a literal placeholder — `${policyViolationReport}`.
> 
> This looks like a bug.

@mdjermanovic, since it's the only real issue in the case, should I extract this particular issue into a separate ticket and then https://github.com/eslint/eslint/issues/15083 can be closed?

> @mdjermanovic, since it's the only real issue in the case, should I extract this particular issue into a separate ticket and then #15083 can be closed?

It isn;t necessary, it's okay to keep this issue open for the problem we've all agreed on, and that is wrapping a starting sequence of string literals in `${}`. If you find some new problems related to this autofix, then it would be better to open a new issue.
